message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Continuous symmetry breaking in a two-dimensional Rydberg array
Paper Abstract: Spontaneous symmetry breaking underlies much of our classification of phases of matter and their associated transitions<sup>1-3</sup>. The nature of the underlying symmetry being broken determines many of the qualitative properties of the phase; this is illustrated by the case of discrete versus continuous symmetry breaking. Indeed, in contrast to the discrete case, the breaking of a continuous symmetry leads to the emergence of gapless Goldstone modes controlling, for instance, the thermodynamic stability of the ordered phase<sup>4,5</sup>. Here, we realize a two-dimensional dipolar XY model that shows a continuous spin-rotational symmetry using a programmable Rydberg quantum simulator. We demonstrate the adiabatic preparation of correlated low-temperature states of both the XY ferromagnet and the XY antiferromagnet. In the ferromagnetic case, we characterize the presence of a long-range XY order, a feature prohibited in the absence of long-range dipolar interaction. Our exploration of the many-body physics of XY interactions complements recent works using the Rydberg-blockade mechanism to realize Ising-type interactions showing discrete spin rotation symmetry<sup>6-9</sup>.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Long-range order"

Links: [{"title":"Long-range order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Long-range_order&redirect=no"},{"title":"Order and disorder - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_and_disorder"},{"title":"Short range order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_range_order"},{"title":"Long-range restriction mapping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-range_restriction_mapping"},{"title":"Structure of liquids and glasses - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structure_of_liquids_and_glasses"},{"title":"Potez-CAMS 141 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potez-CAMS_141"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about long-range order:

## Definition

Long-range order characterizes physical systems in which remote portions of the same sample exhibit correlated behavior.

## How It Works

If the correlation function decays to a constant value at large distances, then the system is said to possess long-range order. If it decays to zero as a power of the distance then it is called quasi-long-range order.

## Examples and Applications

Long-range order is a key concept in condensed matter physics. Systems typically are ordered at low temperatures; upon heating, they undergo one or several phase transitions into less ordered states. Examples for such order-disorder transitions are: the melting of ice (solid–liquid transition, loss of crystalline order) and the demagnetization of iron by heating above the Curie temperature (ferromagnetic–paramagnetic transition, loss of magnetic order).(no content)The degree of freedom that is ordered or disordered can be translational (crystalline ordering), rotational (ferroelectric ordering), or a spin state (magnetic ordering).

## Contrast with Short-Range Order

The structure of liquids, glasses and other non-crystalline solids is characterized by the absence of long-range order which defines crystalline materials. Liquids and amorphous solids do, however, possess a rich and varied array of short to medium range order.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about long-range order:

## Definition

Long-range order characterizes physical systems in which remote portions of the same sample exhibit correlated behavior.

## How It Works

If the correlation function decays to a constant value at large distances, then the system is said to possess long-range order. If it decays to zero as a power of the distance then it is called quasi-long-range order.

## Examples and Applications

Long-range order is a key concept in condensed matter physics. Systems typically are ordered at low temperatures; upon heating, they undergo one or several phase transitions into less ordered states. Examples for such order-disorder transitions are: the melting of ice (solid–liquid transition, loss of crystalline order) and the demagnetization of iron by heating above the Curie temperature (ferromagnetic–paramagnetic transition, loss of magnetic order).(no content)The degree of freedom that is ordered or disordered can be translational (crystalline ordering), rotational (ferroelectric ordering), or a spin state (magnetic ordering).

## Contrast with Short-Range Order

The structure of liquids, glasses and other non-crystalline solids is characterized by the absence of long-range order which defines crystalline materials. Liquids and amorphous solids do, however, possess a rich and varied array of short to medium range order.

Here are the search results for "Rydberg atom":

## Definition

A Rydberg atom is an excited atom with one or more electrons that have a very high principal quantum number, n. The higher the value of n, the farther the electron is from the nucleus, on average.

## Key Properties

Rydberg atoms are extremely large, with loosely bound valence electrons, easily perturbed or ionized by collisions or external fields.(no content)The radius of the orbit scales as n² (the n = 137 state of hydrogen has an atomic radius ~1 μm) and the geometric cross-section as n⁴.

## Historical Background

The existence of the Rydberg series was first demonstrated in 1885 when Johann Balmer discovered a simple empirical formula for the wavelengths of light associated with transitions in atomic hydrogen. Three years later, the Swedish physicist Johannes Rydberg presented a generalized and more intuitive version of Balmer's formula that came to be known as the Rydberg formula.

## Modern Applications

Rydberg atoms have practical applications in quantum computing. A neutral atom quantum computer is a type of quantum computers built out of Rydberg atoms; this type has many commonalities with trapped-ion quantum computers.

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Superradiant phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superradiant_phase_transition"},{"title":"Rapid phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Sublimation (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublimation_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Deposition (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deposition_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Phase change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_change"},{"title":"Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_Transitions_and_Critical_Phenomena"},{"title":"Talk:Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phase_transition"}]

## Phase Transition

I found comprehensive information about phase transitions. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Basic Concept

A phase transition (or phase change) is the physical process of transition between one state of a medium and another, commonly referring to changes among the basic states of matter: solid, liquid, gas, and in rare cases, plasma.

### How Phase Transitions Occur

A phase transition usually occurs when the pressure or temperature changes and the system crosses from one region to another, like water turning from liquid to solid as soon as the temperature drops below the freezing point.(no content)During a phase transition, certain properties of the medium change as a result of changes in external conditions such as temperature or pressure, which can be a discontinuous change; for example, a liquid may become gas upon heating to its boiling point, resulting in an abrupt change in volume.

### Types of Phase Transitions

Beyond the standard solid-liquid-gas transitions, phase transitions include several other phenomena:

- The change from one crystal structure to another, from a crystalline solid to an amorphous solid, or from one amorphous structure to another are examples of solid to solid phase transitions.
- Phase transitions can also describe the change between different kinds of magnetic ordering, with the most well-known being the transition between the ferromagnetic and paramagnetic phases of magnetic materials, which occurs at the Curie point.
- Sublimation is the transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas state, without passing through the liquid state.

### Special Cases

A quantum phase transition is a phase transition between different quantum phases at zero temperature, and can only be accessed by varying a physical parameter—such as magnetic field or pressure—at absolute zero temperature.

Links: [{"title":"Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnetic_dipole–dipole_interaction"},{"title":"Intermolecular force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermolecular_force"},{"title":"File:Three State Model Electric Dipole interaction.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Three_State_Model_Electric_Dipole_interaction.svg"},{"title":"Dipole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole"},{"title":"Electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Ewald summation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ewald_summation"},{"title":"London dispersion force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_dispersion_force"},{"title":"Dipole (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Non-covalent interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-covalent_interaction"},{"title":"Spin–orbit interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin–orbit_interaction"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about dipole interactions:

## Overview

Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction, also called dipolar coupling, refers to the direct interaction between two magnetic dipoles. More broadly, dipole interactions encompass several types of electromagnetic interactions between dipoles.

## Types of Dipole Interactions

**Dipole-Dipole Interactions (Keesom Interactions)**

These forces originate from the attraction between permanent dipoles (dipolar molecules) and are temperature dependent, consisting of attractive interactions between dipoles that are ensemble averaged over different rotational orientations of the dipoles.(no content)The energy of a Keesom interaction depends on the inverse sixth power of the distance, unlike the interaction energy of two spatially fixed dipoles, which depends on the inverse third power of the distance.

**Dipole-Induced Dipole Interactions (Debye Force)**

A dipole-induced dipole interaction (Debye force) is due to the approach of a molecule with a permanent dipole to another non-polar molecule with no permanent dipole, which causes the electrons of the non-polar molecule to be polarized toward or away from the dipole of the approaching molecule.

**London Dispersion Forces**

London dispersion forces are a type of intermolecular force acting between atoms and molecules that are normally electrically symmetric; that is, the electrons are symmetrically distributed with respect to the nucleus.

## Behavior in Electric Fields

In a non-uniform electric field a dipole may receive a net force since the force on one end of the dipole no longer balances that on the other end, and this net force is generally parallel to the dipole moment.

These forces originate from the attraction between permanent dipoles (dipolar molecules) and are temperature dependent, consisting of attractive interactions between dipoles that are ensemble averaged over different rotational orientations of the dipoles.(no content)The energy of a Keesom interaction depends on the inverse sixth power of the distance, unlike the interaction energy of two spatially fixed dipoles, which depends on the inverse third power of the distance.

**Dipole-Induced Dipole Interactions (Debye Force)**

A dipole-induced dipole interaction (Debye force) is due to the approach of a molecule with a permanent dipole to another non-polar molecule with no permanent dipole, which causes the electrons of the non-polar molecule to be polarized toward or away from the dipole of the approaching molecule.

**London Dispersion Forces**

London dispersion forces are a type of intermolecular force acting between atoms and molecules that are normally electrically symmetric; that is, the electrons are symmetrically distributed with respect to the nucleus.

## Behavior in Electric Fields

In a non-uniform electric field a dipole may receive a net force since the force on one end of the dipole no longer balances that on the other end, and this net force is generally parallel to the dipole moment.

Links: [{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz–Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Nicolet 1080 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolet_1080"},{"title":"Ford Falcon (XY) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(XY)"},{"title":"Cutter location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutter_location"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.

## Key Characteristics

The spins in the XY spin system can be represented as an arrow pointing in some direction, or as being represented as a point with some color.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model differs depending on dimensionality:

- **One dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition

- **Two dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.(no content)The Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless (BKT) transition is a phase transition of the two-dimensional (2-D) XY model in statistical physics. It is a transition from bound vortex-antivortex pairs at low temperatures to unpaired vortices and anti-vortices at some critical temperature.

- **Three and higher dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.(no content)Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.

Web search results for query: "Goldstone boson"

Links: [{"title":"Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Talk:Goldstone boson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_field_theory"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudo-Goldstone_boson"},{"title":"Goldstone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goldstone"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"},{"title":"Composite Higgs models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composite_Higgs_models"},{"title":"Nambu–Jona-Lasinio model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nambu%E2%80%93Jona-Lasinio_model"},{"title":"Technicolor (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technicolor_(physics)"},{"title":"Jeffrey Goldstone - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeffrey_Goldstone"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Goldstone bosons:

## Definition and Properties

Goldstone bosons or Nambu–Goldstone bosons (NGBs) are bosons that appear necessarily in models exhibiting spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries.(no content)They are massless if the spontaneously broken symmetry is not also broken explicitly.

## Discovery and Development

They were discovered by Yoichiro Nambu within the context of the BCS superconductivity mechanism, and subsequently elucidated by Jeffrey Goldstone, and systematically generalized in the context of quantum field theory.

## Goldstone's Theorem

Goldstone's theorem states that under spontaneous symmetry breaking, every broken continuous global symmetry leads to a massless field called the Goldstone boson.(no content)There is one scalar particle—called a Nambu–Goldstone boson—for each generator of the symmetry that is broken.

## Pseudo-Goldstone Bosons

If the symmetry is not exact, i.e. if it is explicitly broken as well as spontaneously broken, then the bosons that emerge are not massless, though they typically remain relatively light; they are called pseudo-Goldstone bosons or pseudo–Nambu–Goldstone bosons.

## Real-World Examples

In fluids, the phonon is longitudinal and it is the Goldstone boson of the spontaneously broken Galilean symmetry. In magnets, the Goldstone bosons are the magnons, i.e., spin waves in which the local magnetization direction oscillates.

Web search results for query: "Ferromagnetism"

Links: [{"title":"Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Category:Ferromagnetic materials - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ferromagnetic_materials"},{"title":"Ferromagnetic superconductor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferromagnetic_superconductor"},{"title":"Talk:Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Category:Ferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Ferromagnetism"},{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Ferrimagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferrimagnetism"},{"title":"Curie temperature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curie_temperature"},{"title":"Superferromagnetism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superferromagnetism"},{"title":"Saturation (magnetic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturation_(magnetic)"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of ferromagnetism based on the search results:

## Definition and Properties

Ferromagnetism is a property of certain materials (such as iron) that results in a significant, observable magnetic permeability, and in many cases, a significant magnetic coercivity, allowing the material to form a permanent magnet.(no content)Ferromagnetism (along with the similar effect ferrimagnetism) is the strongest type and is responsible for the common phenomenon of everyday magnetism.

## Common Ferromagnetic Materials

Relatively few materials are ferromagnetic; the common ones are the metals iron, cobalt, nickel and most of their alloys, and certain rare-earth metals.(no content)A common example of a permanent magnet is a refrigerator magnet.

## How Ferromagnetism Works

Ferromagnetism results from these materials having many unpaired electrons in their d-block (in the case of iron and its relatives) or f-block (in the case of the rare-earth metals), a result of Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity.

## Types of Ferromagnetic Materials

Ferromagnetic materials can be divided into magnetically "soft" materials (like annealed iron) having low coercivity, which do not tend to stay magnetized, and magnetically "hard" materials having high coercivity, which do.

## Applications

Ferromagnetism is widely used in industrial applications and modern technology, in electromagnetic and electromechanical devices such as electromagnets, electric motors, generators, transformers, magnetic storage (including tape recorders and hard disks), and nondestructive testing of ferrous materials.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's a comprehensive overview of ferromagnetism based on the search results:

## Definition and Properties

Ferromagnetism is a property of certain materials (such as iron) that results in a significant, observable magnetic permeability, and in many cases, a significant magnetic coercivity, allowing the material to form a permanent magnet.(no content)Ferromagnetism (along with the similar effect ferrimagnetism) is the strongest type and is responsible for the common phenomenon of everyday magnetism.

## Common Ferromagnetic Materials

Relatively few materials are ferromagnetic; the common ones are the metals iron, cobalt, nickel and most of their alloys, and certain rare-earth metals.(no content)A common example of a permanent magnet is a refrigerator magnet.

## How Ferromagnetism Works

Ferromagnetism results from these materials having many unpaired electrons in their d-block (in the case of iron and its relatives) or f-block (in the case of the rare-earth metals), a result of Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity.

## Types of Ferromagnetic Materials

Ferromagnetic materials can be divided into magnetically "soft" materials (like annealed iron) having low coercivity, which do not tend to stay magnetized, and magnetically "hard" materials having high coercivity, which do.

## Applications

Ferromagnetism is widely used in industrial applications and modern technology, in electromagnetic and electromechanical devices such as electromagnets, electric motors, generators, transformers, magnetic storage (including tape recorders and hard disks), and nondestructive testing of ferrous materials.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_simulator"},{"title":"Cirq - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirq"},{"title":"Hamiltonian simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_simulation"},{"title":"IBM Quantum Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Quantum_Platform"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Quantum computational chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computational_chemistry"},{"title":"QuTiP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/QuTiP"},{"title":"Sofie Lindskov Hansen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sofie_Lindskov_Hansen"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Quantum robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_robotics"}]

## Quantum Simulator

Based on the search results, here's an overview of quantum simulators:

### Definition and Purpose

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion.(no content)In this instance, simulators are special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

### Why Quantum Simulators Are Needed

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

### Experimental Platforms

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

### Applications and Recent Developments

Recently quantum simulators have been used to obtain time crystals and quantum spin liquids.(no content)A trapped-ion simulator, built by a team that included the NIST, can engineer and control interactions among hundreds of quantum bits (qubits).

### Software Tools

For simulating quantum systems computationally, there are also software tools available. QuTiP, short for the Quantum Toolbox in Python, is an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems.

## Search Results for Antiferromagnetism

Here's comprehensive information about antiferromagnetism from the web search results:

### Definition and Basic Concept

In materials that exhibit antiferromagnetism, the magnetic moments of atoms or molecules, usually related to the spins of electrons, align in a regular pattern with neighboring spins (on different sublattices) pointing in opposite directions.(no content)When no external field is applied, the antiferromagnetic structure corresponds to a vanishing total magnetization.

### Historical Background

The phenomenon of antiferromagnetism was first introduced by Lev Landau in 1933.(no content)Generally, antiferromagnetic order may exist at sufficiently low temperatures, but vanishes at and above the Néel temperature – named after Louis Néel, who had first identified this type of magnetic ordering.(no content)Above the Néel temperature, the material is typically paramagnetic.

### Examples of Antiferromagnetic Materials

Antiferromagnetic materials occur commonly among transition metal compounds, especially oxides. Examples include hematite, metals such as chromium, alloys such as iron manganese (FeMn), and oxides such as nickel oxide (NiO).

### Applications

This provides the ability to "pin" the orientation of a ferromagnetic film, which provides one of the main uses in so-called spin valves, which are the basis of magnetic sensors including modern hard disk drive read heads.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of symmetry breaking based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This collapse is often one of many possible bifurcations that a particle can take as it approaches a lower energy state.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

There are two main types: symmetry breaking can be distinguished into explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking**: Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical. A common analogy is a ball rolling down from the peak of a dome into a trough, breaking the rotational symmetry of the system.

## Importance in Physics

This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and it plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## The Higgs Mechanism

The 1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers were written by three teams—Robert Brout and François Englert; Peter Higgs; and Gerald Guralnik, C. Richard Hagen, and Tom Kibble—credited with the theory of the Higgs mechanism and the prediction of the Higgs field and Higgs boson.(no content)They showed how gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.

## Biological Applications

Symmetry breaking also occurs in biology: symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of symmetry breaking based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This collapse is often one of many possible bifurcations that a particle can take as it approaches a lower energy state.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

There are two main types: symmetry breaking can be distinguished into explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking**: Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical. A common analogy is a ball rolling down from the peak of a dome into a trough, breaking the rotational symmetry of the system.

## Importance in Physics

This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and it plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## The Higgs Mechanism

The 1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers were written by three teams—Robert Brout and François Englert; Peter Higgs; and Gerald Guralnik, C. Richard Hagen, and Tom Kibble—credited with the theory of the Higgs mechanism and the prediction of the Higgs field and Higgs boson.(no content)They showed how gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.

## Biological Applications

Symmetry breaking also occurs in biology: symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Ising model"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

Here are the search results for the Ising model:

## Overview

The Ising model (or Lenz–Ising model), named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics.(no content)The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).

## Structure and Interactions

The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

## Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition.(no content)The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

## Significance and Applications

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)Today, each year, about 800 papers are published that use the model to address problems in such diverse fields as neural networks, protein folding, biological membranes and social behavior.

I've found comprehensive information about magnetic dipole-dipole interaction. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction, also called dipolar coupling, refers to the direct interaction between two magnetic dipoles.

## Basic Properties

The magnetic field of a dipole goes as the inverse cube of the distance, and the force of its magnetic field on another dipole goes as the first higher power of distance. More specifically, one characteristic of a dipole field is that the strength of the field falls off inversely with the cube of the distance from the magnet's center.

## Force Between Dipoles

The most elementary force between magnets is the magnetic dipole–dipole interaction. If all magnetic dipoles for each magnet are known then the net force on both magnets can be determined by summing all the interactions between the dipoles of the first magnet and the dipoles of the second magnet.

## Quantum Mechanical Description

For quantum systems, if γ₁ and γ₂ are gyromagnetic ratios of two particles with spin quanta S₁ and S₂, the interaction Hamiltonian is expressed with terms involving the magnetic constant μ₀, the spins, and their relative position.

## Applications

Magnetic dipole-dipole interactions are important in various contexts, including residual dipolar coupling (RDC), which provides information on the global folding of proteins and long-distance structural information, as well as information about "slow" dynamics in molecules.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've found comprehensive information about magnetic dipole-dipole interaction. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Magnetic dipole–dipole interaction, also called dipolar coupling, refers to the direct interaction between two magnetic dipoles.

## Basic Properties

The magnetic field of a dipole goes as the inverse cube of the distance, and the force of its magnetic field on another dipole goes as the first higher power of distance. More specifically, one characteristic of a dipole field is that the strength of the field falls off inversely with the cube of the distance from the magnet's center.

## Force Between Dipoles

The most elementary force between magnets is the magnetic dipole–dipole interaction. If all magnetic dipoles for each magnet are known then the net force on both magnets can be determined by summing all the interactions between the dipoles of the first magnet and the dipoles of the second magnet.

## Quantum Mechanical Description

For quantum systems, if γ₁ and γ₂ are gyromagnetic ratios of two particles with spin quanta S₁ and S₂, the interaction Hamiltonian is expressed with terms involving the magnetic constant μ₀, the spins, and their relative position.

## Applications

Magnetic dipole-dipole interactions are important in various contexts, including residual dipolar coupling (RDC), which provides information on the global folding of proteins and long-distance structural information, as well as information about "slow" dynamics in molecules.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
